abstract.text: An AppKit view that hosts a SwiftUI view hierarchy.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: objects to integrate SwiftUI views into your
AppKit view hierarchies. A hosting view is an
SwiftUI view, which may itself contain other SwiftUI views. Because it is an
into your existing AppKit view hierarchies to implement portions of your UI.
For example, you can use a hosting view to implement a custom control.
A hosting view acts as a bridge between your SwiftUI views and your AppKit
interface. During layout, the hosting view reports the content size
preferences of your SwiftUI views back to the AppKit layout system so that
it can size the view appropriately. The hosting view also coordinates event

abstract.text: Declare the user interface and behavior for your app on every platform.
An AppKit view controller that hosts SwiftUI view hierarchy.
An AppKit menu with menu items that are defined by a SwiftUI View.
Options for how hosting views and controllers manage aspects of the
associated window.
Options for how hosting views and controllers reflect their
content’s size into Auto Layout constraints.
An AppKit view that hosts a SwiftUI view hierarchy.
Creates a hosting view object from the contents of the specified
archive.
Creates a hosting view object from an archive and the specified
SwiftUI view.
Creates a hosting view object that wraps the specified SwiftUI view.
Called when the user presses a key on the keyboard while this view is in
the responder chain.
Called when the user releases a key on the keyboard while this view is
in the responder chain.
The root view of the SwiftUI view hierarchy managed by this view
controller.
The safe area regions that this view controller adds to its view.
The options for which aspects of the window will be managed by this
hosting view.
The options for how the hosting view creates and updates constraints
based on the size of its SwiftUI content.
Create a consistent UI animation experience across SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit.
A type that represents part of your app’s user interface and provides
modifiers that you use to configure views.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
A set of methods that are implemented by the source object in a dragging session.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A protocol that a custom class can adopt to manage the enabled state of a UI element.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
